Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I was standing on the sidewalk, my hand entwined with Mia’s, trying to soak in every second of our last weekend together before she left for London. We’d planned this day for weeks—just the two of us, no interruptions. But as we waited for our coffee, I spotted my stepbrother, Ethan, across the street. He was fiddling with his phone, headphones in, and started to step off the curb, oblivious to the car speeding toward him. My heart lurched. I knew Mom always counted on me to look out for him, especially since Dad remarried. But Mia squeezed my hand, her eyes searching mine, wanting me to stay, to be present, to make this moment count. I felt torn in two—my responsibility to Ethan pulling me one way, my promise to Mia tugging the other. My mind raced, guilt and panic colliding, as I stood frozen between the two people who needed me most.
